description: Amplitude damping describes the irreversible loss of energy from a qubit, causing decay from the excited state |1⟩ to the ground state |0⟩. This is the quantum analog of classical dissipation and is characterized by the T1 relaxation time.

Unlike dephasing, amplitude damping is asymmetric: it preferentially drives the qubit toward |0⟩. This breaks the symmetry between computational basis states and cannot be described as a Pauli channel.

In superconducting qubits, T1 is typically limited by dielectric losses, quasiparticle tunneling, or coupling to spurious two-level systems. T1 times of 100-500 μs are common in modern transmon qubits.

properties.Parameters: γ ∈ [0, 1] = damping probability; T1 = relaxation time
properties.Asymmetry: |1⟩ decays to |0⟩, but not vice versa

physical_examples: Spontaneous emission in atoms and ions
qem_considerations: Not a Pauli channel, so Pauli twirling does not fully symmetrize it
ZNE can work but noise scaling may be nonlinear
PEC requires non-Pauli operations for exact cancellation
Virtual distillation/purification can help by amplifying the dominant eigenstate
Often combined with T2 effects: total decoherence rate is 1/T2 ≥ 1/(2T1)
